title: Items
text: Items are basic items created in the Inventory module. Here, you can configure additional properties that only relate to self-serve apps. Your item can be used as a main item in a bundle or as a selectable item in a bundle group. You can also assign any modifier groups to the item in this section. Item List Use the item list to identify and click which item you would like to edit or view more details about. To create a new item you will need to use the Inventory module. Item Details Clicking on an item will display the Item Details screen where self-serve related properties can be edited. NOTE: As these items are linked to Inventory, some properties will be overwritten if you edit them via Inventory. These are highlighted below with an *asterisk Item No A unique identifier assigned to a specific product. Name This is the name that appears on the basket and receipt of your self-serve applications. It's assigned during basic item setup in Inventory. If needed, an alternative name can be assigned on the Composer tile. Image This is the image assigned to the item in Inventory. If needed, an alternative image can be assigned to the Composer tile. Active If the item is active or not. Inactive This option hides the item from view in certain screens. The POP application and barcode scanning will take this into consideration before presenting the item. Active State is ignored if a Composer tile is linked to the item. Display Catagory This determines if the item is sent to the Order Status Display when sold. You can select previously entered display categories from the dropdown or add a new one by typing into the same dropdown. Restricted Quantity This determines if the item, when sold in the Self Checkout, requires manager approval for selling due to age related restrictions. Tags Tags can provide a flattened hierarchy. You can link Composer Tiles to one or more tags to create a dynamic list of items in the front-end apps. For instance, a range of food items can be tagged as "gluten-free," "vegan," or "containing nuts." Note that tags are given at item creation, and you can refer to @Tags for more information.
description:
Items are basic items created in the Inventory module. Here, you can configure additional properties that only relate to self-serve apps. Your item can be used as a main item in a bundle or as a selectable item in a bundle group. You can also assign any modifier groups to the item in this section. 


Item List

Use the item list to identify and click which item you would like to edit or view more details about.

To create a new item you will need to use the Inventory module.



Item Details

Clicking on an item will display the Item Details screen where self-serve related properties can be edited.

NOTE: As these items are linked to Inventory, some properties will be overwritten if you edit them via Inventory. These are highlighted below with an *asterisk



Item NoA unique identifier assigned to a specific product.
NameThis is the name that appears on the basket and receipt of your self-serve applications. It's assigned during basic item setup in Inventory. If needed, an alternative name can be assigned on the Composer tile. 
ImageThis is the image assigned to the item in Inventory. If needed, an alternative image can be assigned to the Composer tile. 
ActiveIf the item is active or not.
InactiveThis option hides the item from view in certain screens. The POP application and barcode scanning will take this into consideration before presenting the item. 
ActiveState is ignored if a Composer tile is linked to the item.
Display CatagoryThis determines if the item is sent to the Order Status Display when sold. You can select previously entered display categories from the dropdown or add a new one by typing into the same dropdown. 
Restricted QuantityThis determines if the item, when sold in the Self Checkout, requires manager approval for selling due to age related restrictions.
Tags
Tags can provide a flattened hierarchy. You can link Composer Tiles to one or more tags to create a dynamic list of items in the front-end apps. For instance, a range of food items can be tagged as "gluten-free," "vegan," or "containing nuts." Note that tags are given at item creation, and you can refer to @Tags for more information.

title: Product Configurator
text: Product Configurator is where you configure your Items, Bundles, Bundle Groups and Modifier Groups these groups all play different roles across the SelfServe applications within Imagine. It is important to know them and how they are used. Items - These are basic items that will have been created in the Inventory module. Here, you configure additional properties that are only related to Self-Serve apps. Your item can be used as a Main item within a Bundle or as a selectable item in a Bundle Group. This is also where you assign any Modifier Groups to the item. Bundles - These are groups of items that you can sell together. A typical example would be a 'Meal Deal'. You select a main item and then make a selection from one or more Bundle Groups to build your meal. Taking the Meal Deal example, your main item would be a sandwich. Then, from one Bundle Group, you would pick a snack, and from another Bundle Group, you would choose a drink. Bundle Groups - These are groupings of similar items from which you would be expected to make a selection. For example, you might have a selection of snacks to choose from. Bundle Group selections have to be items and can only be linked to Bundles. Modifier Groups - These provide you with the opportunity to make certain prescribed modifications to an Item. You can only make modifications to an Item or a Bundle Main item, not a Bundle Group Item. An example of a modification would be choosing between white or brown bread for your sandwich. Below explains the relationships of supported types which can be added as a Composer Tile for your self-serve apps. Using the Meal Deal example to explain the relationships. Item = [Sandwich] Modifier Group = [white or brown bread] Bundle = [Meal Deal of sandwich with snack and drink] Item = [Sandwich] Modifier Group = [white or brown bread] Bundle Group = [Snack] Item A = [Crisps] Item B = [Popcorn] Item C = [Nuts] Bundle Group = [Drink] Item D = [Cola] Item E = [Lemonade] The Example below is of a Bundle which has Modifier Groups linked to the main item. You have a tab for your Selections and a tab for your Modifiers. If you were to just select the main item, you would only see the Modifiers.
description:
Product Configurator is where you configure your Items, Bundles, Bundle Groups and Modifier Groups these groups all play different roles across the SelfServe applications within Imagine. It is important to know them and how they are used.


Items - These are basic items that will have been created in the Inventory module. Here, you configure additional properties that are only related to Self-Serve apps. Your item can be used as a Main item within a Bundle or as a selectable item in a Bundle Group. This is also where you assign any Modifier Groups to the item.


Bundles - These are groups of items that you can sell together. A typical example would be a 'Meal Deal'. You select a main item and then make a selection from one or more Bundle Groups to build your meal.

Taking the Meal Deal example, your main item would be a sandwich. Then, from one Bundle Group, you would pick a snack, and from another Bundle Group, you would choose a drink.


Bundle Groups - These are groupings of similar items from which you would be expected to make a selection. For example, you might have a selection of snacks to choose from. Bundle Group selections have to be items and can only be linked to Bundles.


Modifier Groups -  These provide you with the opportunity to make certain prescribed modifications to an Item. You can only make modifications to an Item or a Bundle Main item, not a Bundle Group Item. An example of a modification would be choosing between white or brown bread for your sandwich.


Below explains the relationships of supported types which can be added as a Composer Tile for your self-serve apps. Using the Meal Deal example to explain the relationships.


Item = [Sandwich]

Modifier Group = [white or brown bread]
Bundle = [Meal Deal of sandwich with snack and drink]











Item = [Sandwich]

Modifier Group = [white or brown bread]
Bundle Group = [Snack]

Item A = [Crisps]

Item B = [Popcorn]

Item C = [Nuts]

Bundle Group = [Drink]

Item D = [Cola]

Item E = [Lemonade]


The Example below is of a Bundle which has Modifier Groups linked to the main item. You have a tab for your Selections and a tab for your Modifiers.


If you were to just select the main item, you would only see the Modifiers.
